授業目的: This course will provide an overview of state government(s) in the United States using Hawaii as an example.  We will examine the relationship between the state and the federal government and distinguish the roles that the three branches―executive, legislature, judiciary―play.
到達目標: We will cover the various “actors” and factors that influence public policymaking.  These include political parties, special interests, and citizen participation.  Furthermore, we will look at the way in which modern campaigns and elections take place in the U.S. Students will learn how to be effective advocates in policymaking in their own communities.
特記事項:
本授業科目は、“オンライン授業60単位制限対象科目”ではありません。
The course is not subject to the 60-credit limit for online courses.
授業方法:
Four writing assignments are required. Each will count at 15 points so a total of 60 points. Class participation and attendance will count for an additional 40 points.
Online attendance is NOT permitted since there will be small group discussions and class participation in person is required.

第2回: What is Politics?  Class discussion on political identity.
第3回: Federalism and the States - The Role of State and Federal Governments.
第4回: Three Branches of State Level Government - Executive, Legislature, Judiciary.
第7回: How to be an Effective Advocate.  Preparing Testimony.
第8回: Mock Hearing - Students will prepare testimony for and against a bill.
第9回: Mock Hearing - Students will prepare testimony for and against a bill.
第10回: Power to the People: The Role of Advocacy in Politics.
第11回: The Have and the Have-Nots: The Role of Class in Politics.
第12回: Power to the Lobbyists: The Role of Lobbyists in Politics
第13回: The Future of Politics in a Flat World.  The Globalization of Politics
